components.description:
A slightly open tabbed folder, as used to file papers in a cabinet or as an icon for an opened folder when using a computer. Most platforms depict a yellow folder, as manila, with the tab shown at the left.

Commonly used for various content concerning filing, organization, and work, especially at an office.

Apple’s folder is gray, Twitter’s is blue. Google’s design features multiple tabs, Microsoft’s a red tab.

Nearly identical in appearance and use to üìÅ File Folder, which is closed.
components.title: Open File Folder

version.description:
Released in October 2010, Unicode 6.0 was the first version of the Unicode Standard to support emoji.

Some characters in prior versions of Unicode were retroactively updated to provide an emoji presentation. This release was the first to introduce new characters for the sole purpose of compatability with emojis being used in Japan.

emoji_net_data.category: Miscellaneous Symbols And Pictographs -> Office symbols
emoji_net_data.definition: An open folder used to store¬†files in a filing cabinet. May be¬†used as an icon for an opened folder when browsing computer files. Open File  http://emojipedia.org/open-file-folder/
emoji_net_data.name: open file folder

bn:00091165v: To cause to open or to become open.
Cause to open or to become open

apple_vendor_description: The open file folder emoji on Apple devices appears as a classic, slightly worn manila folder, rendered with Apple's signature glossy 3D shading and soft rounded edges. Subtle shadows and highlights give it a tangible feel, suggesting its readiness to hold important documents. This emoji is commonly used to signify organization, documents, information, or the act of saving and accessing files within digital systems.
